Symptoms: Dark, sunken lesions on leaves and fruit; fruit shows concentric rings and may rot entirely.
Causes: Caused by the fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa
Treatment: Use resistant varieties, prune infected limbs, and avoid overhead watering.
Recommendations: Apply fungicides like captan or thiophanate-methyl

Symptoms: Shiny green leaves, no signs of lesions or spots, and healthy fruit development.
Causes: Proper care, no disease presence, and suitable environmental conditions.
Prevention: Continue good agricultural practices, regular monitoring, and balanced fertilization.
Recommendations: Maintain hygiene and monitor for any disease symptoms periodically.

Symptoms: Olive-green to black spots on leaves and fruit
Causes: leaves may curl and fall early.
Prevention: Caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis
Treatment: favored by wet and cool weather.
Recommendations: Use resistant cultivars, prune for air circulation, and avoid overhead irrigation.

Symptoms: Orange or rust-colored spots on apple leaves
Causes: galls with spore horns on cedar trees.
Prevention: Caused by the fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae
Treatment: needs both apple and cedar trees to complete lifecycle.
Recommendations: Remove nearby cedar trees or apply fungicides preventively.

Symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit that become dark and sunken.
Causes: Caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria
Prevention: spreads through water splashes and contaminated tools.
Treatment: Use certified disease-free seeds, avoid working in wet fields, and rotate crops.
Recommendations: Copper-based bactericides may reduce spread but not cure infected plants.

Symptoms: Bright green leaves, firm stems, and healthy pepper fruits.
Causes: Healthy growing conditions and absence of pathogens.
Prevention: Follow proper spacing, fertilization, and watering practices.
Recommendations: Monitor for pests or signs of disease regularly.

Symptoms: Glossy green foliage, no visible leaf spots or fruit damage.
Causes: Well-managed plant with adequate care and no disease exposure.
Prevention: Maintain regular watering, mulching, and pruning schedules.
Recommendations: Stay vigilant during flowering and fruiting stages for early detection of issues.

Symptoms: White powdery fungal growth on the surface of leaves, buds, and shoots.
Causes: Caused by Podosphaera clandestina; thrives in warm, dry conditions.
Prevention: Ensure good air flow through pruning
Recommendations: Apply sulfur or potassium bicarbonate sprays.

Symptoms: Green upright leaves, strong stems, and well-formed ears of corn.
Causes: Absence of disease and optimal growing conditions.
Prevention: Maintain crop rotation, weed control, and proper irrigation.
Recommendations: Continue scouting and maintain fertility programs.

Symptoms: Reddish-brown pustules on both upper and lower leaf surfaces.
Treatment: Grow resistant hybrids and maintain field sanitation.
Recommendations: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin when infection level is high.

Symptoms: Dark green, healthy leaves with firm tubers and no visible lesions.
Causes: Proper crop management and disease-free conditions.
Prevention: Continue integrated pest management and regular monitoring.
Recommendations: Maintain crop hygiene and rotate with non-solanaceous crops.

Symptoms: Dark, concentric ring lesions on lower leaves, yellowing, and leaf drop.
Causes: Caused by Alternaria solani; thrives in warm, humid weather.
Prevention: Crop rotation, mulching, and resistant varieties help prevent.
Treatment: Fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb can manage outbreaks.
Recommendations: Apply fungicides early and remove infected debris from fields.
